docs.lead_paragraph: Conservative objections over spending are raising doubts over whether the U.S. Senate can quickly approve legislation fixing the Medicare physician payment system, in a possible setback for Republicans keen to show they can get things done.

headline.main: U.S. Conservatives Threaten Delay to Fixing Medicare Doctor Payments
headline.print_headline: U.S. Conservatives Threaten Delay to Fixing Medicare Doctor Payments

docs.lead_paragraph: General Electric has transformed in the past decade. The Fairfield, Connecticut, company slimmed itself down from a massive conglomerate that made microwaves, movies and jet engines to a trimmer company focused on its industrial business. It has sold or spun off businesses that don't fit with its industrial goals, such as NBC Universal and its credit card business.

headline.main: GE Then and Now: A Look at How the Company Has Changed
headline.print_headline: GE Then and Now: A Look at How the Company Has Changed

docs.snippet: General Electric has transformed in the past decade. The Fairfield, Connecticut, company slimmed itself down from a massive conglomerate that made microwaves, movies and jet engines to a trimmer company focused on its industrial business. It has sold...

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans aren’t saving enough for retirement, and Social Security isn’t currently big enough to fill the gap. So why not make it bigger?
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column applauds proposal by some Democratic lawmakers to expand Social Security benefits; holds that, counter to antigovernment propaganda being pushed by Republicans, there are some areas, including retirement benefits, where government is more effective than private sector; contends Social Security program works very well and that lawmakers should build on that success.
docs.snippet: Americans aren’t saving enough for retirement, and Social Security isn’t currently big enough to fill the gap. So why not make it bigger?

docs.lead_paragraph: Lynne Thomas Gordon of the American Health Information Management Association writes that “patients have a right to request a copy of their health records” from their doctors.
docs.snippet: Lynne Thomas Gordon of the American Health Information Management Association writes that “patients have a right to request a copy of their health records” from their doctors.

docs.lead_paragraph: It became the first state to ban the safest method of ending a second-trimester pregnancy.

headline.main: Kansas Tries to Stamp Out Abortion
headline.print_headline: Kansas Tries to Stamp Out Abortion

docs.abstract: Editorial deplores decision by Kansas to ban abortion procedure known as dilation and evacuation, common and safe process for ending second-trimester pregnancy; criticizes ban as part of overarching effort to restrict women's reproductive freedom and to impose lawmakers' moral beliefs on decisions best left to doctor and patient.
docs.snippet: It became the first state to ban the safest method of ending a second-trimester pregnancy.

headline.main: Turning to Big, Big Data to See What Ails the World

docs.abstract: A new measurement system that includes disabilities from disease and disaster offers a surprising view of public health.
docs.snippet: A new measurement system that includes disabilities from disease and disaster offers a surprising view of public health.

docs.lead_paragraph: A legislative push in Montana to extend Obamacare health coverage to the working poor advanced on Thursday after a last-minute reprieve thanks to a procedural play by supporters, even as similar efforts in other conservative states are flagging.

headline.main: Obamacare Push Powers Ahead in Montana, Fading in Other States
headline.print_headline: Obamacare Push Powers Ahead in Montana, Fading in Other States

docs.snippet: A legislative push in Montana to extend Obamacare health coverage to the working poor advanced on Thursday after a last-minute reprieve thanks to a procedural play by supporters, even as similar efforts in other conservative states are flagging.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Chinese department store in Manhattan, which opened in 1971, has been a welcome alternative to restaurant and supermarket jobs for immigrant workers. It will close in December because of a significant rent increase.

headline.main: At Pearl River, Four Decades of Helping New Arrivals From Asia
headline.print_headline: For 4 Decades, Serving as Lifeline for Immigrants

docs.abstract: Manhattan's Pearl River Mart, department store that is slated for closure amid rising rent, served as cultural refuge and employment lifeline for Chinese immigrants since it opened in 1971.
docs.snippet: The Chinese department store in Manhattan, which opened in 1971, has been a welcome alternative to restaurant and supermarket jobs for immigrant workers. It will close in December because of a significant rent increase.

keywords.value: Pearl River Mart (Manhattan, NY, Retail Store)
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Only a third of banks were found to require companies they do business with to notify them of a breach. The outside companies include everything from data providers to cleaning crews.

headline.main: Wall St. Is Told to Tighten Digital Security of Partners
headline.print_headline: Wall St. Is Told to Tighten Digital Security of Partners

docs.abstract: New York State Dept of Financial Services superintendent Benjamin M Lawsky says survey of 40 banks has found that they are not diligent enough about oversight of cybersecurity protocols at outside firms with which they do business; survey finds numerous lapses, but Lawsky says institutions have time to improve their oversight, underscoring importance of ratcheting up security for everyone involved.
docs.snippet: Only a third of banks were found to require companies they do business with to notify them of a breach. The outside companies include everything from data providers to cleaning crews.
